awd_abstract_narration:
Whether stepping on the brake pedal when a hazard appears in the road ahead, beginning a sprint in response to the starter's pistol, or reaching to catch a tipping glass, we possess a remarkable ability to respond rapidly and accurately to demands for action. These responses occur within a reaction time of around 250 milliseconds, during which we must perceive the need to act, decide precisely what action to take, and generate motor commands to coordinate the activity of dozens of muscles to make the movement. It is currently not clearly understood what steps in this pathway take the greatest amount of time, which brain regions are responsible for which computations, and whether or not the reaction time could be reduced even lower. With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. John Krakauer and colleagues Dr. Adrian Haith, Dr. Pablo Celnik and Dr. Joshua Ewan will use innovative behavioral experiments with human participants to stress the limits of the reaction time and tease apart its constituent processes and limitations. They will record brain activity during these same tasks (using EEG) in order to identify the underlying brain networks responsible and will apply non-invasive brain stimulation to establish the specific function of these brain networks in generating rapid motor responses.

A number of neurological disorders, such as Parkinson disease, are associated with slowing of motor responses. Such symptoms are not well-understood at present. The knowledge gained from this study will yield important insights as to why this slowing may occur and what, if anything, could be done to treat it from a therapeutic and/or clinical perspective. A deeper understanding of the reaction time will also be of significant interest to those seeking to push the limits of human performance, such as athletes and race car drivers, or amateurs seeking to better their own performance. Furthermore, data collected in this study are likely to be of broad interest and therefore will be made available to other researchers. EEG recordings will be of particular interest to researchers developing advanced analytical techniques for mapping human brain activity. Finally, students from under-represented minorities, including those from economically disadvantaged backgrounds, will have the opportunity to directly participate in this project and gain valuable research experience through the Johns Hopkins Diversity Summer Internship Program.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated what determines how quickly we are able to react to external events. For instance, how quickly can a goalkeeper react to block a penalty in soccer? Measuring the 'reaction time' (as it is termed in psychology and neuroscience) to different types of cues is a fundamental approach to understanding the types of computations that occur in our brains prior to making a movement.

Prior theories have often assumed that the reaction time reflects the amount of time required for the brain to compute what to do. Our research revealed, however, that reaction times are much slower than they need to be. A typical reaction time to reach to a visual target is about 250 ms. We found, however, that people were capable of perfect performance even if they were forced to respond at as a little as 170 ms. This suggests that one third (80 ms) of the typical reaction time (250 ms) is unnecessary.

An important finding in this project, which offers and explanation for this 80 ms 'slack' in the reaction time, is that preparing WHAT to do and deciding WHEN to act are governed by distinct and independent processes in the brain. This finding has far-reaching consequences in neuroscience and psychology and has, since we first reported it, been widely corroborated by independent research groups

We examined a number of factors that are known to influence reaction times, in order to determine whether these should be attributed to improved preparation, or simply to earlier initiation. We found that repetition and practice improved the speed of preparation, while ageing slowed the speed of preparation. However, the timing of movement initiation could also be habitual. If people performed a task that required very low reaction times, they would carry this 'habit' to other tasks, even if it was detrimental to overall performance.

We also examined the processes that lead up to a response in more challenging tasks. In particular, we studied tasks in which there may be a conflict between two different potential responses to a stimulus. For instance, if a knife falls off the kitchen counter, there may be conflicting urges to catch a falling object, versus to get out of the way of the sharp knife. By forcing people to move at very low reaction times, we could reliably control which response they would be most likely to emit. At long reaction times they would select the right response ("avoid"), but if forced to move very early, they would consistently do the wrong thing ("catch"). This finding reveals how conflicts of action selection become resolved, with 'reflexive' responses being prepared automatically, then replaced when a better response becomes available.

This same approach also applies to situations where people must override a previously learned habit. For instance, when driving a car with the steering wheel on the opposite side of the car, the handbrake and gear stick are in a different place, and the driver must override their habitual patterns of behavior to avoid reaching into the door. Our approach in this project provides a novel way to study habits and has revealed that it is possible for a 'latent' habit to exist, undetected, but can be revealed by forcing people to respond very quickly.

A number of young scientists received important training during the course of this project. In addition to allowing training for a postdoc and research assistant supported by this grant, several undergraduate research assistance were able to participate in this research and gain valuable research experience.

Each summer during the course of this project, we participated in the Johns Hopkins Internship in Brain Sciences project enabling high school students from under-represented minorities in the Baltimore area to gain exposure to brain science. These internships were very successful. One intern in particular is now pursuing a career in brain science following his experience.
